Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now lets identify which are significantly longer. The average would be: (2.25 + 25.17 + 1.33 + 24.17 + 49.08) / 5 = 102 / 5 = 20.4 hours So cases taking significantly longer than average would be: Case 105: 49.08 hours (much longer) Case 102: 25.17 hours (slightly above average) Case 104: 24.17 hours (slightly above average) Cases 102, 104, and 105 are all above average, but 105 is exceptional. Lets also look at the median to better understand significantly longer. The sorted times are: 1.33, 2.25, 24.17, 25.17, 49.08. Median is 24.17 hours. So cases significantly longer than median: 105 (49.08 hours) is almost double the median.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Let me calculate the active vs idle time more precisely for each case: Case 101: All transitions are immediate, no idle time Active time: 2h 15m = total time Case 102: Day 1: 08:05-08:30: Triage (25m) 08:30-09:00: Wait (30m) 09:00-11:30: Wait before escalation (2.5h) 11:30-14:00: Wait after escalation (2.5h) 14:00-09:00(next day): Investigation overnight (19h) Day 2: 09:00-09:15: Resolve and close (15m) Active time: 25m + 19h investigation + 15m = ~19h 40m Idle/wait time: 30m + 2.5h + 2.5h = 5.5h Total: 25h 10m Case 103: Active time: 1h 20m = total time, no idle time Case 104: Day 1: 08:20-09:00: Triage (40m) 09:00-09:30: Wait (30m) 09:30-13:00: Wait before investigation (3.5h) 13:00-08:00(next day): Investigation overnight (19h) Day 2: 08:00-08:30: Resolve and close (30m) Active time: 40m + 19h + 30m = ~20h 10m Idle/wait time: 30m + 3.5h = 4h Total: 24h 10m Case 105: Day 1: 08:25-08:35: Triage (10m) 08:35-09:00: Wait (25m) 09:00-09:10: Wait (10m) 09:10-10:00: Investigation (50m) 10:00-14:00(next day): Wait after escalation (28h) Day 2: 14:00-09:00(next day): Investigation overnight (19h) Day 3: 09:00-09:30: Resolve and close (30m) Active time: 10m + 50m + 19h + 30m = ~20h 30m Idle/wait time: 25m + 10m + 28h = 28h 35m Total: 49h 5m (approx matches)

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now I can clearly see the root causes: 1. Escalation delays: Cases with escalations (102, 105) have significantly longer resolution times. The handoff between Level-1 and Level-2 agents introduces substantial delays, especially in case 105 where theres a 28-hour gap. 2. Investigation scheduling: Cases 102, 104, and 105 all have investigations that span overnight (19-hour duration), suggesting that investigation activities are not being completed within a single shift or business day. This could be due to: Complexity requiring extended investigation Agents working only during business hours Lack of urgency/priority Waiting for customer response or additional information 3. Queue/waiting times: Before investigation begins, there are significant delays: Case 102: 2.5h wait before escalation, 2.5h wait after escalation Case 104: 3.5h wait before investigation These suggest bottlenecks in agent availability or workload distribution 4. Triage efficiency: Case 104 took 40 minutes to triage vs 10-25 minutes for others, suggesting inconsistent triage processes or complexity in initial assessment.
